newsitem.title: CANADA: Manitoba blizzard to cause century's worst flood.
newsitem.headline: Manitoba blizzard to cause century's worst flood.

text.p: A blizzard that dumped 57.4 cms (23 inches) of snow on Manitoba's Red River Valley over the weekend was forecast to cause the worst flood of the century, Winnipeg's Harbour Master said.
"This storm didn't help any, it'll make it the worst flood of the century," Winnipeg Harbour Master Joe Pietracci said.
An average flood is seven feet, four inches above the summer level of the Red River at Winnipeg's James Avenue Station. Flood level at 0700 CDT Monday was eight feet, three inches, he said.
The peak flood reached 19 feet, four inches above summer level, he said.
"The river's rising about two feet a day. We're getting water from North Dakota, South Dakota and down the Assiniboine River from the Shellmouth (Reservoir)," Pietracci said.
Manitoba's Red River Valley produces wheat, barley, canola, corn and flax.
The Canadian Wheat Board on Monday forecast spring seeding in the Valley would likely be delayed by a few weeks.
